Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my bank app, the numbers glaring back at me. My stepson’s hopeful eyes from this morning replayed in my mind—he’d been counting down the days to the Nintendo I’d promised him. I wanted to keep my word, to show him he could trust me, that I could provide the things he dreamed about. But my phone buzzed again: a message from work. The machines in the shop were running hot, overdue for maintenance. If I didn’t get in soon, we risked a costly breakdown, maybe even lost contracts. My boss expected me to be reliable, to keep everything running smoothly. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family’s happiness and security on one side, my professional responsibility and the company’s trust on the other. I could only be in one place, spend the money once. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out which promise I’d have to break.
